Point. Within this Point, to the westward,
his Majesty's ship Raisonable was lost, off
Fort and Point Gardie; this Point therefore
must be avoided. Here we were informed
that the Admiral and Fleet were at anchor
in Diamond Cove or Road.
The Diamond Rock, which lay's more than a
mile from the shore, bears from Point Saline
W. N. W. distance 7 or 8 miles. The
aforesaid Rock is high and round, and to
the N. W. of it is Diamond Cove or Bay,
where we found his Majesty's Fleet at anchor,
the 16th of January 1762, under the
command of Rear Admiral Rodney, and the
next day we landed his Majesty's Troops in
Cass Navire Bay; but as the Antigua Brig.
was ordered to the northward, I chose to
go with her, in order to go to Jamaica, and
so we proceeded to Guadaloupe, where we
found a sloop from Lisbon, from Capt. Johnston
of the Hornet, which gave us an account
of a Spanish War, and the Captain gave me
a Copy of the King of Spain's Declaration.
As the Lieutenant Governor sent the Brigantine
back to Martinico, I thought it my
best way to go back with her; but as a ship
then at Guadaloupe (the Alexander, Captain
Atkinson) was ready, or would be in two or
three days, I was determined to secure myself
a passage, and agreed with him, in case
I should be disappointed at Martinico, as it
